entry.title: Re: Tax Compliance Tool
entry.content:
Hello Harish

Thank you for your question.

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) is designed to manage key VAT compliance processes. It covers activities such as extracting transactional data, preparing VAT returns, enabling electronic submissions, and providing workflow approvals with full audit trails. The compliance calendar also helps keep track of important deadlines, and workflow notifications can be set up through DRC or integrated SAP workflow tools.

However, it‚Äôs important to note that VAT payment execution itself is not handled directly within DRC. Payment tracking usually requires support from SAP‚Äôs financial modules. The ‚ÄòRun Statutory Reports‚Äô FIORI app mainly focuses on statutory report generation and submission, so it does not address the entire VAT lifecycle.

In summary, DRC offers strong end-to-end VAT reporting, submission, and workflow features, while VAT payment tracking is typically managed through financial system integration.

Best regards,

John

entry.title: Re: How to rewrite this ABAP SQL join via the CDS associations and SQL Path Expression?
entry.content:
Hi @Sandra_Rossi , 

You can rewrite the SQL Queries as CDS views like this , 

I have directly converted the SQL query to CDS : 

1. 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center
  as select from I_PrelimBillingDocumentItem as PBDI
    inner join   I_SalesDocument             as SD  on SD.SalesDocument = PBDI.SalesDocument
    inner join   I_PurchaseOrderItem         as POI on POI.PurchaseOrder = SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer
{
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument,
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocumentItem,
  PBDI.SalesDocument,
  SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer,
  POI.CostCenter
}
where
      PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument =  'PBD0000061'
  and POI.CostCenter             <> ' '

IF you want to keep the PrelimBillingDocument as a parameter , you can also do the same like :

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center
  with parameters
    p_PrelimBillingDocument : prelim_billing_document
  as select from I_PrelimBillingDocumentItem as PBDI
    inner join   I_SalesDocument             as SD  on SD.SalesDocument = PBDI.SalesDocument
    inner join   I_PurchaseOrderItem         as POI on POI.PurchaseOrder = SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer
{
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument,
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocumentItem,
  PBDI.SalesDocument,
  SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer,
  POI.CostCenter
}
where
      PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument = $parameters.p_PrelimBillingDocument
  and POI.CostCenter             <> ' '

2. First create a view like : 

 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center

  as select from I_PrelimBillingDocumentItem as PBDI
  association to I_SalesDocument     as _salesdocument        on _salesdocument.SalesDocument = PBDI.SalesDocument
  association to I_PurchaseOrderItem as __zzpurchaseorderitem on __zzpurchaseorderitem.PurchaseOrder = $projection.PurchaseOrderByCustomer

{

  PBDI.CostCenter,
  PBDI.SalesDocument,
  _salesdocument.PurchaseOrderByCustomer as PurchaseOrderByCustomer,
  _salesdocument,
  __zzpurchaseorderitem
}
where
  PBDI.CostCenter <> ' '

and on top of this create another view like : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center2'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center2

  as select from ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center as BDCC


{

  PBDI.CostCenter,


  _salesdocument,
  __zzpurchaseorderitem
}

Hope it Helps üôÇ

entry.title: Planned vs Unplanned Depreciation Behavior after Post-Capitalization
entry.content:
Description:

Client Requirement (with example):

  • Asset capitalization: 100,000
  • Useful life: 10 years ‚Üí planned depreciation = 10,000/year
  • After 2 years, 20,000 depreciation should already be recognized.
  • Remaining depreciation = 80,000, to be spread across 8 years ‚Üí 10,000/year.
  • Expected: System should spread depreciation based on remaining NBV (80,000) and remaining useful life (8 years)

Testing Performed:

  1. Created an asset with acquisition value 100,000, UY = 10.
  2. Posted Unplanned Depreciation = 20,000.
  3. Changed useful life to 8 years.

Problem Observed:

  • With Planned Depreciation Key ‚Üí system distributes planned depreciation automatically, but does not allow unplanned depreciation postings.
  • With Manual Depreciation Key ‚Üí unplanned depreciation can be posted, but planned depreciation is no longer distributed.
  • This means the system is not handling both requirements together (automatic periodic depreciation + extraordinary depreciation).

We have tested the following scenario to meet the client‚Äôs requirement:

  1. Posted an acquisition with 10-year useful life and depreciation key LINS (which distributes depreciation automatically).
  2. Posted Unplanned Depreciation = 20,000. For this, we had to temporarily change the depreciation key to manual, since LINS did not allow the posting.
  3. This enabled unplanned depreciation, but removed the distribution of planned depreciation.
  4. After posting unplanned depreciation, we attempted to reduce the useful life to 8 years and switch the depreciation key back to LINS.At this stage, the system throws an error, as unplanned depreciation has already been posted.

We understand this may be standard system behavior and would appreciate it if you could confirm this. Additionally, if possible, please suggest an approach to achieve the client‚Äôs requirement in S/4HANA

entry.title: Limiting Agent Autonomy ‚Äì Least Privilege and Tool Access for Agentic AI Systems
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the second part in a series on agentic AI security. The first can be found here.

In the previous blog in this series, we covered the non-deterministic nature of agentic AI systems and the repudiation threats involved with that. To help reduce the attack surface and provide greater resilience to these and other STRIDE threats, few strategies are better than limiting what an agent is allowed to do. We must restrict access to tools and systems to agents and authorize them only to what they need to complete their tasks. Just as we do with human users or non-human service accounts.

 

Agent IAM and the Principle of Least Privilege

Identity and Access Management (IAM) and Identity Governance and Administration (IGA) are established pillars of cybersecurity. IAM governs access to tools and applications based on your role and function in an organization. Regular users have different access privileges than administrators. The general accepted advice in security and compliance is to apply the principle of least privilege. That is, only apply those authorizations that are necessary for users to accomplish their tasks and perform their functions, but not more.

The same principle applies to system accounts. Application and system users similarly need to be restricted. In large monolithic applications this can be difficult to achieve when the system must perform many privileged talks. Microservices architecture offers the advantage of applying more granular authorizations to individual system components. We allow one component to have database access to record transactions but restrict it from exposure to the public internet. Meanwhile, another receives API requests from the internet but doesn‚Äôt need a database connection. Yet another microservice can function as a request dispatcher, limited to communication to other system components.

Human users notoriously find ways to accomplish their tasks in creative ways. System accounts stick to their assigned function even when overprivileged, and the key risk is that such accounts are compromised and abused by malicious human actors. AI agents unpredictably misbehave. By decomposing system functionality into more granular agents with narrow focus and scope, we gain more control points to reduce misaligned behavior.

 

Tool and System Access

The first layer of tool and system access for agents is with a system account. This works best where the access to the service has no distinction in authorizations between different users.

Consider an agentic AI system that analyzes sales reports for a retail chain and annotates anomalous weekly movement up or down with external events. Such events could be local news, sports or cultural events, regional holidays and weather reports with an impact on overall sales or sales categories. Unexpected, pleasant warm weather can explain an increase in sales in sunglasses, bathing suits and ice cream, while pending snowstorms clarify unexpected sales increases in canned and frozen goods. A county fair or key home team match can be the reason weekend shopping is down. The system uses a central orchestration agent, supported by specific agents to collect news, local event calendars and weather information from 3rd-party services. Each of these services provides full access to their database for search over the entire dataset for subscribed customers with an API key.

In this case, it is trivial to restrict the weather agent ‚Äì and only the weather agent ‚Äì to only be allowed to search historical weather reports. The orchestrator agent must only provide a date or date range of any anomalous results for a particular location to the weather agent to operate. It has no need or purpose for the sales data. Similarly, an agent looking for local news events that could impact sales only needs a date range for a summary of local news.

We need to limit the weather agent identity to only perform the task it‚Äôs intended to do. If the weather agent can only ever contact the weather service and no other resource on the internet, even when the agent displays non-deterministic behavior it produces nothing more than a weather report. Suppose that somehow an instruction asks the agent to look up other resources, it would only be able to reply with weather information. It can‚Äôt send e-mails if the agent has no access to a mail server.

In the examples above, limits are applied by authorizations applied to the agent‚Äôs role. However, that assumes that we trust the agent. That is not necessarily guaranteed, especially in a multi-party agentic AI system ‚Äì for instance where the weather agent is a third party service or has been compromised. An orchestrator agent that delegates tasks to other agents can limit the weather agent‚Äôs capabilities on the task level, overriding any overprivileged role-based authorizations.

Limiting an agent to only the role and tasks it is supposed to do greatly reduces the risks of misalignment to its goals. For such cases where there are no different access levels for the user of the system, such controls work well.

 

Act in the Context of the User

However, we should consider the sales report ‚Äì that data needs to come from somewhere as well, typically a business application with more refined access rights and restrictions. Our example agentic AI system with a business data agent collecting and analyzing the sales results needs to consider that not all the systems users likely have access to the same level of information. A regional manager may only be able to see results from a particular region, a store manager only for their own store. System access doesn‚Äôt restrict the agent enough, as the agent could be persuaded to share information from other regions. Agents with access to business systems need to act as a delegate and adopts the user's access and authorizations for any particular request.

An agentic AI system allowed to make transactions in business systems should only allow users to perform tasks they are authorized to do otherwise in the business application. Users using an agentic AI system to book travel must only be able to book their own along the same privileges if they logged on to SAP Concur. Agents should only have access to HR and payroll information the user has in SAP SuccessFactors. Users using an agentic AI purchasing system must be prevented from ordering expensive laptops for an entire team if they aren't authorized to do so in SAP Ariba. For access to critical systems with established access right dependent on one‚Äôs role and function in an organization agents must act within the context of the user. Such agents must essentially assume its role and identity in the system.

Similarly, if you‚Äôre building your own agentic AI system, ensure that you apply this same principle of user context for appropriate access to restricted databases, business applications and cloud services. A system account alone with broad access isn‚Äôt sufficient to prevent unauthorized disclosure of restricted information. It will be impossible to reliably replicate and control the users‚Äô roles and authorization in the source systems. Meanwhile, the business systems already have all the authorizations the user needs, hopefully under the same least privilege principle.

 

Segregation of Duties

The separation can be further narrowed down. An agent that reads a sales catalogue and selects options for a user to pick from doesn‚Äôt need to be the same agent that ultimately executes the purchase order. An agent that is only allowed to search through the catalogue can never accidentally order something. A purchasing agent, on the other hand is far more likely to behave when it is given a clear instruction to purchase a specific list of items but can‚Äôt search the catalogue to inadvertently add other items.

Separation of duties between different agents with different functions - reading from access-controlled business systems compared to processing or initiating transactions ‚Äì in the design of the agentic AI system makes it more resilient to model misbehavior. When we restrict the authorization for the agent to only search the catalogue, it can never make purchases before the human buyer approves it. Similarly, restricting the purchasing agent from searching the catalog prevents it from adding any items the human buyer didn‚Äôt select.

 

Agents as Potential Threat Actors

As we saw in part one, when threat modeling agentic AI system, we can‚Äôt only account for malicious users in the tradition cybersecurity sense. Regular users can trigger misaligned behavior. But agents themselves have agency ‚Äì that is, they have autonomy to act, even when limited. They are actors in the system, even if not conscious actors. Therefore, it is important that designers and developers of agentic AI systems consider that during threat modeling and build in the appropriate protections. Secure Agentic design introduces the concept of ‚ÄúArchitectural Constraints,‚Äù as discussed in this article, which are powerful concepts that help eliminate an entire class of threats against agents and language model misbehavior. These hard controls are essential in designing secure agents.

In part three, we will discuss an architecture pattern that provides such constraints.

 

More Information

  • Principle of Least Privilege (Wikipedia)
  • ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Not What We Agreed!‚Äù ‚Äì Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling (SAP Community)
  • OWASP Agentic AI ‚Äì Threats and Mitigations

entry.title: Re: Cannot Post Goods Receipt (Movement Type 101) against...
entry.content:
Hi @phanideepthiakula,

Partial goods receipt should also be possible with API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT.

Were you able to post the goods receipt using 'MIGO' or 'Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document' successfully?

Please check the confirmation control key in your purchase order items and if there are missing confirmations or if the purchase order expects an Inbound Delivery due to the settings of the confirmation control key.

Could you also please provide your payload?

Here you can find some easy examples: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3f57e7df4a114edabffe8b2d581a59ed/8bb0d08295044ee3af444b4f2a6e4457.html

 

best regards

entry.title: SAP, AI, and Cloud: A New Era of Enterprise Systems
entry.content:
SAP Today: A Technical Perspective

When we talk about SAP today, it‚Äôs no longer just about ERP. The platform now integrates with AI, machine learning, and cloud technologies. For example, SAP S/4HANA supports real-time analytics. Instead of waiting hours for batch reports, finance and operations teams can work with live data and speed up decision-making.

Integration is another key area. Many organizations run multiple systems: CRM, HR, supply chain, and more. SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) provides a framework that lets these systems communicate. That reduces data duplication, cuts manual steps, and gives more reliable outcomes.

There is also a notable shift toward sustainability and compliance. SAP includes capabilities to track carbon footprints, manage ESG data, and meet global reporting standards. This is now a requirement in many industries, and the platform provides tools to handle the related complexity.

From a technical view, the migration path is important. Moving from ECC to S/4HANA is not just a technical upgrade it requires rethinking processes. Many organizations use the migration to automate workflows, add predictive analytics, or connect IoT devices to ERP. It is as much transformation as it is technology.

In short, SAP is evolving beyond an ERP backbone into a digital core covering analytics, integration, compliance, and automation. The convergence of SAP with AI and cloud-native apps will continue to deepen this role.

entry.title: Re: Customer be originated in SAP CX (Sales Cloud V2)
entry.content:
Hi, 

In one of my previous projects we also had to make a similiar decision. There were already several checks and validations build (duplicate checks/address validation etc.) in S/4 in the customer create proces but with the introdution of C4C v1 there was a need to support the proces from this system as well. In the end we decided to create a custom SAP UI5 app on S/4HANA and embed this in C4C with a mash-up (new custom workcenter). In this way we could leverage the already existing S/4 functionality in customer create proces. 

KR,

Simon

Application rationalization enables businesses to reduce costs while preserving core business capabilities. This session will demonstrate how to systematically analyze your application portfolio, identify cost-saving opportunities, and implement optimization initiatives using proven frameworks. In this session, we'll guide you through the process of evaluating your current application landscape, share best practices for assessment, and provide actionable strategies you can implement in your organization.

entry.title: Re: How to create a Cash Flow Statement?
entry.content:
Hi @Brian,

For month-over-month calculations in MDX, you can use PrevMember instead of [Prior], like:

[NetAR].CurrentMember - [NetAR].CurrentMember.PrevMember

This gives the difference between the current and previous month. For more complex calculations across multiple accounts, using Account Transformation logic can help automate and simplify the process.

Best regards,

John

entry.title: How to recover from Decommissioning
entry.content:
Dear SAP Support Team,

 

We are currently reviewing our SAP Solution Manager configuration and would like to inquire about the recovery procedures in the event of the following hypothetical actions:

 

„ÉªDecommissioning of SOLMAN_SETUP
„ÉªClearing of DBA Cockpit settings
„ÉªClearing of RFC connections

which disk drives are backed up when restoring a virtual server consisting of two machines with the system installed?

 

Could you please advise on:
„ÉªRecommended recovery steps


--- Support Assistant ---

entry.title: From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach
entry.content:
From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach

We recently wrote a blog about how we integrate data from a REST service into SAP Datasphere. For that we deployed a small service on SAP BTP, which used the OPEN SQL schema and FastAPI to write this data directly into Datasphere. That service could also be triggered via REST endpoint from SAP Datasphere directly (ZPARTNER Link, SAP Community Link).

In this blog we now choose a different setup to retrieve data and consume it into SAP Dataphere.

We Created a CAP Application on SAP BTP.

This CAP service connects to the SCIM API of SAP Datasphere, extracts users and roles, and makes the data consumable for analytics. It uses the following BTP services:

  • HDI Container
    To persist our data from the REST calls. The HDI container is deployed to the HANA Cloud instance of our Datasphere tenant, so the data can be consumed directly.
  • BTP Credential Store
    We store the credentials for the SCIM API in the BTP Credential Store and retrieve them in our CAP application securely.
  • XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management
    To secure our REST endpoints and enforce token-based access control.
  • Cloud Foundry Space
    Provides the runtime environment for deploying the CAP application.

Use Case

In our use case, we extract user information from SAP Datasphere‚Äôs own SCIM API.

We retrieve:

  • the list of users,
  • all available roles, and
  • the assignments between users and roles.

This can be helpful for reporting on the number of users in a tenant and their corresponding roles. However, the same setup can be reused to extract and process any other REST API data into SAP Datasphere.

Credential Store

We create a dedicated namespace in the Credential Store and store four secrets for the SCIM API authentication flow:

  • dsp-scim-token-url
  • dsp-scim-base-url
  • dsp-scim-client-id
  • dsp-scim-client-secret

The CAP application retrieves these secrets at runtime, ensuring no credentials are hardcoded.

XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management Service

We create a dedicated xsuaa service to get a Token URL and credentials. This service is bound to our CAP application so that every incoming request is authorized and protected.

HDI Container

We create an HDI container where the database artifacts (tables and associations) are deployed. This container is provisioned in our SAP Datasphere tenant, making the synchronized data directly available for consumption.

CAP Application

The heart of the solution is the CAP service DSPUsers.

It exposes two kinds of endpoints:

Virtual Views (live from SCIM)

  • GET /data/UsersVH ‚Üí List of users with profile info.
  • GET /data/RolesVH ‚Üí Roles with aggregated user counts.
  • GET /data/UserRolesVH ‚Üí Which users have which roles.

These views are always fresh, since they query SCIM directly.

Persistent Entities (stored in HDI)

  • GET /data/Users ‚Üí Users persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/Roles ‚Üí Roles persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/UserRoles ‚Üí User-to-role assignments persisted in HANA.

Actions (to sync SCIM ‚Üí HDI)

  • POST /data/SyncUsersVHToUsers ‚Üí Upserts SCIM users into the Users table.
  • POST /data/SyncRolesFromSCIM ‚Üí Stores aggregated roles in the Roles table.
  • POST /data/SyncUserRolesFromSCIM ‚Üí Refreshes both Roles and UserRoles.

This design lets you both query SCIM data live and persist snapshots into HANA for modeling in Datasphere.

The complete CAP service code is available here: Link to GitHub Repository.

SAP Datasphere

Once deployed, the HDI container is automatically integrated with our SAP Datasphere tenant. This allows:

  • Consuming the Users, Roles, and UserRoles tables directly in Datasphere,
  • Building reporting scenarios on top of user and role data,
  • Joining with other business data to enrich analytics.

To consume the entities, we need to add the HDI Container to a specific space. Also, we can now create a generic HTTP Connection. This enables to call the Endpoints for sync in a Task Chain.

Conclusion

The integration of a CAP-based service into SAP Datasphere showcases how SAP BTP services (HDI Container, Credential Store, XSUAA, Cloud Foundry) can be combined to securely retrieve and persist data from external REST APIs. By consuming SAP Datasphere‚Äôs own SCIM API, we demonstrated how to expose both live views for real-time insights and persistent tables for analytical modeling, all within a lightweight and extensible architecture.

Looking ahead, this framework can be reused for any REST API integration into SAP Datasphere, opening the door to richer reporting scenarios, advanced data modeling, and seamless orchestration with Task Chains. With this foundation, organizations gain a simple but powerful pattern for bridging external services with Datasphere while maintaining enterprise-grade security and governance.

entry.content:

Ie.

Sender cost center  $100

Receiver cost center A , actual activity type 5 Hours

Receiver cost center B, actual activity type 15 Hours

After Template Allocation run:

Receiver cost center A  100/2=50

Receiver cost center B 100/2=50

How can I realize this requirement? Which Function should I use in CPT3 and how to write the formula?

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: How to handle the auto. creation of costing views in...
entry.content:
The reason the costing view is created in the selection step is that the costing run is a preparatory step. Even if a material is V-priced, it might be a component in a higher-level product's Bill of Material (BOM). To perform the cost roll-up for the final product, the system needs a valid cost estimate (a cost component split) for every component, which is why it selects them and creates the view even if it's only to calculate a "statistical" standard cost that won't be used for inventory valuation.

Primary Solution: Excluding Materials from Selection (best practice)

There is no standard checkbox in the CK40N selection screen to exclude materials based on their Price Control (V). The field is not available in the standard dynamic selections.

The most effective ways to exclude materials are:

A. Exclude by Procurement Type (Best Standard Option)

For materials intended to be on price control V (like Raw Materials), they should typically have a Procurement Type (MARC-BESKZ) of F (External Procurement).

B. Exclude by Material Type or Material Number Range

If your Price V materials belong to specific Material Types (e.g., ROH for Raw Materials, VERP for Packaging), you can exclude these types directly in the initial CK40N selection screen.

Second solution: Preventing View Creation or Costing (Alternative Method)

Use the "Do Not Cost" Indicator

This is the most direct control in the material master:

  • Go to the Costing 1 view of the Price V material master (MM02).

  • Set the Do Not Cost indicator (CKMLHD-XKALK).

Materials with this indicator checked will be explicitly excluded from selection and BOM explosion in a costing run. This is a clean, master data-driven way to prevent costing for a material.

entry.title: Re: Cannot Post Goods Receipt (Movement Type 101) against...
entry.content:
Hello @phanideepthiakula 

Thank you for reaching out and your questions

PO-based GR (101) is supported through the OData V2 API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV.

Set the header with GoodsMovementCode=01 and, for each item, specify GoodsMovementType=101, GoodsMovementRefDocType=B, along with PurchaseOrder, PurchaseOrderItem, and quantity/unit.

You can also optionally include Batch and StorageLocation. Enable this feature via SAP_COM_0108. Business Accelerator Hub-Material Documents-Read,Create

Your 400 error (‚ÄúProperty PURCHASEORDER/DELIVERY is not supported for 101‚Äù) usually occurs when GoodsMovementCode and/or GoodsMovementRefDocType aren‚Äôt set correctly. SAP KBA shows a valid payload for 101 with a PO. SAP Support Portal-3630337 - Error LB/031 when posting subcontracting purchase order through API in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Inbound-delivery-based GR: use Inbound Delivery (A2X) OData V2 and its PostGoodsReceipt action (comm scenario SAP_COM_0106). To post a partial GR, first PATCH the item quantity, then call PostGoodsReceipt.          Business Accelerator Hub-Inbound Delivery(A2X)

OData V4 api_inbound_delivery_gm is not released for external consumption in Public Cloud,no API Hub entry,. Stick to the released V2 services (or the SOAP service below). Business Accelerator Hub-Inbound Delivery(A2X)

SOAP fallback (delivery-referenced GR): Material Document ‚Äì Create is also delivered under SAP_COM_0108. SAP Help Portal-APIs for Sourcing and Procurement-Material Document - Create

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

 

Enablement of the mapping

  • SAP_COM_0108 ‚Üí OData V2 Material Documents to Read, Create and SOAP Material Document ‚Äì Create) Business Accelerator Hub-Material Documents-Read, Create
  • SAP_COM_0106 ‚Üí OData V2 Inbound Delivery (A2X) with PostGoodsReceipt action. Business Accelerator Hub-Inbound Delivery(A2X)

entry.title: Re: User Id locked BODS are automated with that id
entry.content:
The user account may have been automatically deactivated due to too many failed login attempts.
Alternatively, the password might have expired, depending on the system‚Äôs configured password expiration policy.
To resolve the issue, it's best to contact your S/4HANA administrator and ask them to check the user's account status.

Hello @phanideepthiakula

Set the header with GoodsMovementCode=01 and, for each item, specify GoodsMovementType=101, GoodsMovementRefDocType=B, along with PurchaseOrder, PurchaseOrderItem, and quantity/unit.

You can also optionally include Batch and StorageLocation. Enable this feature via SAP_COM_0108. Business Accelerator Hub-Material Documents-Read,Create

entry.title: Enable Joule to Pass Requests to Microsoft Copilot and Teams
entry.content:
This blog shows you how to integrate Microsoft Copilot and Teams with Joule so that your users can have conversational interactions that include content about integrated Microsoft applications. With the previous blog, we established the technical infrastructure so that Microsoft and SAP systems trust each other and exchange any required tokens for the two systems to interact. In the next steps, we add the required API permissions for Microsoft Graph.

The following figure shows our target architecture.

Prerequisites

  • You've configured your tenants SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID to trust each other. 
    You need the TenantId which you noted down during the registration of your federation app in Microsoft Entra ID.
  • You've set up conditional authentication for Joule.

For details, see our previous blog Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID for Joule.

Configure Your Microsoft Entra ID Tenant

Go to the Entra ID Admin Center with the admin user role.

Configure API Permissions

  1. Go to Home > Identity > Applications > App registrations.
  2. Choose your federation app.
  3. Choose API permissions.
  4. Choose Add a permission.
  5. Choose Microsoft Graph.
  6. Add the following permissions:
    • Sites.Read.All
    • Mail.Read
    • People.Read.All
    • OnlineMeetingTranscript.Read.All
    • Chat.Read
    • ChannelMessage.Read.All
    • ExternalItem.Read.All
  7. Choose Add Permissions.
  8. Choose Grant Admin Consent {Entra_ID_Tenant_Name} and chooseYes.

    Give it a Go

    If everything is configured correctly, you can open your Joule client and ask, "What is in my calendar today?" Joule should check with Copilot and return your calendar information from Microsoft Outlook (assuming you use Microsoft Outlook). If Joule doesn't answer, you might have made a mistake in following these blogs or we may have a bug to iron out. Go carefully through this setup and make sure you have it right. If you are still having trouble, our support team will be happy to help you. Use support component CLT-COP.

    Conclusion

    Your landscape is configured to pass on conversations started in a Joule application in Microsoft Copilot and Teams to a Joule agent, which in turn queries further Joule agents integrated with the landscape.

entry.title: Fixing the ‚ÄúMore Members Available‚Äù Issue in SAP Analysis for Office based on Custom CDS Views
entry.content:
While working with SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and SAP Analysis for Office (AFO), you may encounter the message: "More Members Available"

This typically appears when filtering or selecting values in prompts, and it indicates that the number of available members exceeds the display threshold. Although SAP provides a configuration setting (FetchMemberLimit) to increase the limit, this doesn‚Äôt always resolve the issue, especially when the value help includes duplicate entries.

Standard Fix: You can try increasing the member limit in AFO:

Go to File > Analysis > Customize Analysis > Technical Configuration
Set FetchMemberLimit to a value higher than the expected number of members.

However, this only works if the number of members is within the new threshold. If duplicate entries exist, the system still struggles to display all entries. In many cases, the issue arises from repeated members in the value help CDS view. This is common when the value help is generated from a custom CDS view without ensuring uniqueness.

To resolve this, modify your value help CDS view to return distinct values.

Syntax

define view XXXXX as select distinct from XXXX
{

}

In previous blogs, we have seen how value help can be generated with help of below annotations.

@Consumption.filter.multipleSelections: true
@Consumption.valueHelp:


Conclusion
The ‚ÄúMore Members Available‚Äù issue in SAP Analysis for Office can be frustrating, but it‚Äôs often solvable with a simple tweak to your CDS view design. By ensuring your value help view returns distinct values, you can improve usability and performance in your embedded analytics reports.

entry.title: Developing cloud-ready Adobe Forms on-premise
entry.content:
Hi all,

we're running S/4 HANA 2023 FP1 on-premise and as part of our clean core strategy, we need to deal with forms as well. As today, we use all available technologies like SAPScript, SmartForms as well as Adobe Forms. For sure, we only stick to Adobe Forms for new forms since several years.

To my understanding, we can use SAP Forms in BTP also on-premise. It will only be a replacement for our on-prem ADS, but there is no need to change any print report or form. So we can still use all the NAST and other stuff available since decades. This only covers infrastructure in my opinion. But what is the difference from a developers perspective?

As we all know, reports are not clean core compliant. This must also be true to print reports you define in customizing. So there will be no print report in future anymore. We actually have no plans to move to cloud but at least I want to be prepared for this. This brings me to my final question

What do we need to consider when it comes to developing SAP Forms in a cloud-ready manner? Where and how should we place our custom logic for custom forms as well as for SAP standard forms (i.e. handling templates for invoices, purchase orders etc.)? How to do this to be able to use the form in both, on-premise as well as cloud?

- do we need to replace the logic from Z-print reports to Z-classes? (we typically do this these days)
- do we need to place custom logic into interface of a form (we do this for standard forms [invoices] to be able to stick to standard print reports)
- anything else we should consider on-premise?

As said, actually there are no plans to move but at least we should be prepared for this. At least we need to refine our development guidelines to reflect any new concept.

Our current approach looks like this:
- in case of totally custom form, any code is handled by dedicated print classes. The classes implement the business logic as well as calling the form FMs
- in case of adopting standard forms, we copy standard form interfaces and add any additional custom code inside this. Same is true for form itself for sure. By this, we can still use standard print reports 
- in any case, we try to avoid mixing both concepts. Code should be either in dedicated print class or in interface but not in both.

I hope someone can give me some hints

Patrick

entry.title: Re: How to call REORG_GENERATE with algorithm ID 14 (Chec...
entry.content:
Hi Philipp,

Indeed, there is limited information about these three additional options. My understanding is as follows, just for your information:

- LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED: The tables and partitions that are already correctly placed according to the table placement rules are left unchanged.
- KEEP_VALID: I don't know the difference from LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED.
- NO_SPLIT: Don't perform splitting of tables or partitions during the reorganization process.

I think in most cases, LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED should be good.

Regarding the command:
> CALL REORG_GENERATE(14, 'LEAVE_UNCHANGED_UNTOUCHED');
It should be correct, as I was able to execute it successfully in my local system.

>And where would I find the results of the checks?
You can find the details via the following SQL:
SELECT * FROM REORG_PLAN_INFOS;

Best regards,
Charles

Thank you to everyone who took the time to share questions, ideas and feedback during the course period ‚Äî your engagement made the learning experience richer for all.

If you‚Äôd still like to share feedback, the following options remain available:

  • Use the smileys below each lesson video to provide feedback on specific content.
  • For technical or general questions, use the Feedback function in the top left corner of the SAP Learning page.

We look forward to seeing you in a future SAP Expert Lecture.

Thank you for choosing SAP Learning!

Kind regards,
Britta Radicke-Schlinsog
(SAP Learning)

entry.title: Re: Field Item: Production Supply Area is a required field for the action Save internal stock transf
entry.content: Before you ask a question, please browse the community in case this question has been answered already. If you need to create a new question, start with a descriptive title that briefly outlines what your question is about. A clear question title will help community members gain a quick initial understanding of your question. It will also help community members find your question (and its answers) when they are searching for solutions to similar problems. When writing your question, please share what steps you took that led you to your question. If you don't, community members might tell you to take actions you've already tried yourself. Make sure that your question is very specific. Provide as many details as you can -- such as which product version you are using and what error message you're receiving. Include screenshots if possible.

entry.title: Re: Have I been kicked out of the community :-(
entry.content: Have you registered to Devtoberfest? Join the Devtoberfest group.

entry.title: Re: Field Item: Production Supply Area is a required fiel...
entry.content: The error is not a bug‚Äîit‚Äôs a mandatory field requirement in SAP EWM for production-related stock transfers. You‚Äôll need to either maintain the PSA (Production Supply Area) in master data or manually enter it during the transfer to proceed

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Central Business Configuration 2506 FD2
entry.content:
With the latest release for SAP Central Business Configuration, an exciting new feature is available. This blog post will provide you with a concise overview.

Enhanced Transparency for Initial Scoping

We‚Äôre excited to announce that you can now quickly identify scenarios that are only selectable during initial scoping, all without leaving SAP Central Business Configuration. In the Define Scope app, the new Selection Allowed filter lets you display scenarios that can only be added initially, not later. This provides clarity on the scope decisions you need to make before confirming your scope for the first time.

Selection Allowed filter in the Define Scope app

To learn more about what's new, use the What‚Äôs New Viewer on the SAP Help Portal, which provides further details and links about all the recent changes.

That wraps up the new features this time. Did you like this blog? If so, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

Do you have any ideas on how to further enhance SAP Central Business Configuration? Go to the Customer Influence platform to submit an improvement request or vote for the ideas of others. This helps us understand your requirements even better and prioritize our work accordingly. We‚Äôre looking forward to your improvement requests.

entry.title: Re: Planned vs Unplanned Depreciation Behavior after Post...
entry.content:
Hi @archana_raut38 

Thank you for your question.

As you mentioned, what you observed is a standard system behaviour in public cloud. Depreciation keys like LINS do not allow switching to manual mode for unplanned postings. Once you post unplanned depreciation with a manual key, you cannot revert back without inconsistencies.

Therefore, posting extraordinary depreciations using the standard transactions type (e.g., 640) while keeping the asset assigned to the planned depreciation key remains the supported approach. After this posting, the system reduces the net book value and automatically recalculated planned depreciation across the remaining useful life. In doing so, the system ensures that:

  • Extraordinary depreciation is recognised immediately.
  • Planned depreciation continues automatically and distributed across the updated net book value and useful life.

The conclusion is you do not need to change depreciation keys. You only need to use the correct transaction type for unplanned depreciation within the standard depreciation framework.

Have a look at Extraordinary Depreciation & Depreciation Keys for more details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Material Master BDC Issue
entry.content:
The recommended approach in Public Cloud is to use OData or SOAP APIs for Product Master (Material Master) creation and updates. You can build a lightweight interface that only passes the 4‚Äì5 fields your customer cares about, while default values for mandatory fields are handled in:

  • Business Configuration (SSCUI settings)
  • Defaulting logic in APIs
  • Custom Business Add‚ÄëIns (BAdIs) in the Cloud (limited but available).

Example: API_PRODUCT_SRV (OData) or Product Master ‚Äì Create/Update SOAP API.

entry.title: Solman Production Build - onprem to Azure migration approaval with dual stack
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

We are planning the migration of our on-premise Solution Manager system (dual-stack: ABAP + JAVA) to Microsoft Azure, and would like your input on the best migration approach considering the following setup:

The system is dual-stack, with ABAP and JAVA sharing a single database instance.
On-prem backups are currently stored on NetApp, while the Azure environment will use Backint for HANA backups.

We have a few specific queries:

Migration Strategy:
What is the recommended migration method for such a dual-stack setup?

Should we consider replication, backup/restore, or a hybrid approach?
How does replication work when both ABAP and JAVA share the same DB? Are there any special considerations?


Backup History Concerns:
In our DEV system, we used: DB restore for ABAP and SWPM export/import for JAVA
However, we noticed that the backup history was lost post-migration.


If we use only DB restore (without replication), will the backup catalog/history be retained?
What is the recommended approach for PROD systems to ensure backup continuity and catalog integrity?

Backup Integration:

Are there any steps needed to ensure smooth transition from NetApp-based backups to Backint on Azure?
Will the existing backup catalog be usable post-migration, or does it require reinitialization?

We‚Äôd appreciate your guidance on the most robust and supportable approach for this migration, especially considering the dual-stack nature and backup history implications.

Thanks & Regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Solman Production Build - onprem to Azure migration a...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Please refer to the answers below for your questions.

What is the recommended migration method for such a dual-stack setup?

  • The recommended and the supported methods with SWPM can be found in the system copy guide: System Copy Guides - Software Provisioning Manager 1.0
  • On the target side, for Java you can choose the backup restore option, but choose that the Database is restored.
  • With normal restore it won't work without SWPM tool, and the Java instance will not start.
  • The Database instance installation is required with the Java instance.

Q: Should we consider replication, backup/restore, or a hybrid approach?
How does replication work when both ABAP and JAVA share the same DB? Are there any special considerations?
=>
A: You can use the system replication for the purpose of system copy.
Please refer to the section '5. Can SAP HANA system replication be used for system copies?' in KBA 1999880 - FAQ:HANA System Replication, and KBA 2472478. https://me.sap.com/notes/2706322
2472478 - How to copy and move tenant databases between SAP HANA systems https://me.sap.com/notes/2472478

There's no hybrid approach which is available for system copy.
 
Q: Backup History Concerns:
In our DEV system, we used: DB restore for ABAP and SWPM export/import for JAVA
However, we noticed that the backup history was lost post-migration.
If we use only DB restore (without replication), will the backup catalog/history be retained?
What is the recommended approach for PROD systems to ensure backup continuity and catalog integrity?
=>
A: If you use backup and restore method, the restore will be using the backup catalog from the backup which was taken from the source system.
Of course, the backup history will be available after the restore.

Regarding tto system copy using backup and recovery, please refer to the following documents.

Copying a Database Using Backup and Recovery 
Copying a Database Using Backup and Recovery(HANA Cockpit) 

Backup Integration:
Are there any steps needed to ensure smooth transition from NetApp-based backups to Backint on Azure?
Will the existing backup catalog be usable post-migration, or does it require reinitialization?
=>
A: Please contact the backint vendor for this question.
You may also refer to KBA 2031547 - Overview of SAP-certified 3rd party backup tools and associated support process.

Best regards,
SAP Support

Any help would be appreciated
